title: Pork Chile Verde
description: A vibrant Mexican-style stew of tender braised pork simmered in a tangy, roasted tomatillo and poblano chile sauce. Bright herbal notes from cilantro and cumin balance the mild heat for a comforting, satisfying main that's perfect with rice or warm tortillas.

ingredients.notes: trim excess fat, cut into uniform chunks

ingredients.display_name: poblano chiles, roasted, seeded and roughly chopped
ingredients.notes: char skin under broiler or on stovetop, peel skins

ingredients.display_name: jalapeño, seeded for milder heat (leave seeds for more heat)
fresh cilantro, stems reserved, leaves chopped
corn tortillas or cooked rice for serving
ingredients.notes: about 2 per person if serving as tacos

steps.text: Preheat the broiler or a hot skillet. Arrange halved tomatillos and whole poblanos on a sheet pan and broil or roast, turning occasionally, until tomatillos are blistered and softened and poblanos are charred on all sides.
Place charred poblanos in a bowl and cover to steam for 10 minutes, then peel, seed, and roughly chop. Allow tomatillos to cool slightly.

In a blender, combine roasted tomatillos, chopped poblanos, jalapeño (if using), chopped onion, garlic, cilantro stems, cumin, oregano, 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/2 teaspoon pepper, and blend to a smooth but slightly textured sauce. Reserve.
Pat pork pieces dry and season with 1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt and remaining pepper. Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed Dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering.
Brown pork in batches, avoiding overcrowding, searing each side until a deep golden crust forms. Transfer browned pork to a plate as batches finish.
Reduce heat to medium, add a splash of chicken stock to the pot to deglaze, scraping up browned bits, then add the blended green sauce and the remaining chicken stock. Stir to combine.

Return all browned pork and any accumulated juices to the pot, bring to a gentle simmer, cover partially, and reduce heat to low. Simmer gently until pork is fork-tender and sauce has thickened, stirring occasionally.
Uncover, increase heat to medium-low, and simmer 8–10 minutes to concentrate flavors and adjust seasoning with additional salt if needed. Stir in lime juice and chopped cilantro leaves off heat.
Let the stew rest 5 minutes. Serve spooned over rice or in warm tortillas and garnish with extra cilantro and lime wedges.
